Posts.Content: Hi Flopsy  I'm learning, as we go through this process, how different the experience and treatment can be for all of us. Also how comforting it is to share individual situations with one another and find some common ground. I had 3 lymph nodes removed during my lumpectomy. I now have one longish scar across the middle of my armpit, with a golf-ball sized swelling underneath it (seroma?). Not painful but a bit uncomfortable, especially at night. We called the nurses on Monday and went into the unit, where they advised best not to drain it, as they usually refill with fluid pdq. I have seen other postings here about seromas, and hoping it will be absorbed naturally, over time. However, I would be interested to hear others views.. Whilst there they removed the dressing on my boob, which I had avoided since the op. Looks OK (better than I'd thought) - slight scarring around the edge of the nipple where they made the incision. Still blue from the dye, but not as bad as the bruising I had after my biopsies, and not really painful. My post-op consultant appt is tomorrow - assuming we will hear the "pathology" and treatment plan then.  Still hoping not to have lymph nodes removed, but we shall see... I should think your surgeon will let you know exactly how many lymph nodes you had removed and the reasons for this when you have your appt? But if you are unable to wait, perhaps it might be worth calling them beforehand, for reassurance. On the positive side, you can see/feel your healing, which is good. Amazing what our bodies are able to do, even when they are fighting! Best Wishes

Posts.Content: Crystaljuju Hi MoMo2626  The1% benefitt is unique to Helens specific diagnosis.  yours may be completely different.  Have a try and see..... http://www.predict.nhs.uk/ You are right though. when you feel the side effects outweigh the benefits that's your cue to question if its worth it. Posts.Title: Predict

Posts.Content: Hello. I was diagnosed weeks after my job interview for a college teaching post and before my start date on 1st Sept. I rang my Head of Dept the day after my diagnosis and offered to withdraw so the college could re-advertise forvthe position. His instant response was "We will support you". The college have been brilliant ever since. I was signed off from 20 Sept and have been given time to have my surgeries and radio before returning (tho I may return sooner). So I would definitely advise you to tell them sooner. Remember you have done nothing "wrong" - no one plans to have cancer. Not the start  you would have wanted, but it cant be helped. NB. Only slight complication for me as a new employee was not qualifying for full sick pay. College have paid Statutory Sick Pay, however. You are also protected under the Equality Act vs discrimination (cancer is civered like a disability would be), so your employer should not treat you differently following your diagnosis.
